direct_answer.text:
First, let's figure out how many cups of lemonade Millie gets from her investment. One batch makes three pitchers, so multiply the capacity of one pitcher (which is 12 cups) by the number of pitchers (three):  
12 cups/pitcher × 3 pitchers = 36 cups.   
Next, divide the amount Millie paid ($3750887) by the number of cups she could potentially get:  
$3750887 / 36 cups = $104191.31 per cup.    
Now knowing that millie charges $1 per cup, subtract the cost per cup from the charge to determine Profit Per Cup Sold. Hence, when calculating these variables separately first before integrating into our original equation :

ost_step.1: One pitcher contains 12 cups. Therefore, if we sold out one batch (three full pitchers), this would result in a sale of \( 3 \times 12 = [eval(3*12)=36]36 \) cups of lemonade.

direct_answer.text:
First, let's calculate the cost per cup of lemonade:
Cost per cup = Total cost / Number of cups made
Cost per cup = $3,750,887 / (3 pitchers * 12 cups/pitcher)
Cost per cup = $3,750,887 / 36
Cost per cup = [eval(3750887/36)=104191.30555555555] approximately $10,419.13

Now, since Millie sells each cup for $1, her revenue per cup is also $1. To find the profit per hour, we need to know how long it takes to sell all 36 cups when averaging 4 cups sold per hour:
Hours to sell all cups = Total cups / Cups sold per hour
Hours to sell all cups = 36 cups / 4 cups/hour
Hours to sell all cups = [eval(36/4)=9] 9 hours
